pullRequest.body:
* Removed dependency on Python to make requests to SageMath, using curl instead
* Moved API calling logic from `scripts/polyrith_sage.py` to `Tactic/Polyrith.lean`
* Moved `scripts/polyrith_sage_helper.py` inline

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

- [x] depends on: #17605

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: messageFile.md
I'm not qualified to review this PR, but I would like to flag for the eventual reviewer that (IIRC) CI doesn't test `polyrith`, so the tests should be checked manually.

@hrmacbeth Correct, all the tests under test/polyrith.lean are commented out (to avoid overloading the SageMath API). I manually checked most of the commented out tests, although there may be some cases I have missed

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#17605~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

Ouch, in #20334 I just modified the python script to allow it to use a local install of Singular or Sage (and use the online service only if that fails).

Maybe that approach could be merged in this PR?

@miguelmarco Hi, I have not updated my PR for some time. I think allowing using local Sage install is more important than my change here. Let's merge your change first and then I can see if my PR can be merged!

@hanwenzhu it seems to me that #20334 by @miguelmarco is somewhat orthogonal to your changes (and also not really fletched out fully yet). I think if you address the review above about keeping the python code as python file which is read at runtime, we could try to get your PR reviewed & merged.

I am a little confused regarding whether to merge this or #20334 first, or to make some other big change to polyrith. But since the suggested change regarding keeping a separate Python file is easy to make, I have updated it here, so there is one less TODO on the list.
My impression is that #20334 is not yet ready to land - so going ahead with this PR seems fine.

I have ran the tests using `polyrith` in `MathlibTest/polyrith.lean` on my Mac laptop, but perhaps just to be safe someone should also test this for Linux and Windows setups (since it involves calling `curl`)
messageFile.md

I suggest 

maintainer merge

I guess the remaining question is that @eric-wieser's suggestion of fully extracting the python code wasn't really achievable (see [this section of the code](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/f95434373839ba5562957ab4b54de3b07094ed4a/Mathlib/Tactic/Polyrith.lean#L311-L339)) mainly due to insertion of variables.

I think the approach here is very sensible. I quickly thought about how to use use something like python's `string.Template` or a custom Lean parser (mirroring `interpolatedStringKind`) to have the python code in a separate file with holes for the Lean variables, but I think that's overcooking way too hard...
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by joneugster.
Instead of using a string template, I think we could just wrap everything in a python function, and then only template the initial variable assignments in the lean code before calling the function?
messageFile.md
messageFile.md
messageFile.md
messageFile.md

LGTM and I see @eric-wieser 's approval: https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17626#discussion_r1927282650

maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by joneugster.

Thanks, this is exciting!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12976296262/job/36188384417)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12976296262/job/36188384518)
The PR looks good to me. I've left a few comments before passing it on
Good catch! Are there any other similar issues in that file? (You *could*, optionally, extract all such fixes into a separate PR - that should be easy to review and merge.)
The main problem with this test file (other than it is commented out) is that part of it was written in Lean 3
I think it would be better to keep this file as a `.py` file, and read it from within Lean.
I have no preference on this, although is there a reason why it should be a separate file? I will make the change later.

The advantage is that this code gets Python syntax highlighting and IDEs can offer Python-relevant suggestions. 

There is an `include_str` macro (in mathlib?) can read the file for you at compile time.

Was this change deliberate?

I see that they aren't needed anymore, but as far as I understand they don't really hurt. (Not an important commment anyways)

```suggestion
  deriving BEq, Repr
```
I don't remember why I did that. I am reverting it back.

same question here

```suggestion
  deriving FromJson, Repr
```

... and here

```suggestion
  deriving FromJson

```

I wasn't aware `polyrith` tests were such a mess ðŸ™ƒ 

I've made a reasonable effort on uncommenting test and checking the ones that aren't broken in the statement (e.g. because they are still Lean3) code. I'm reasonably confident that no tests are newly broken by the PR and that the PR author made the required effort on ensuring this, too.
I also tested the ones that aren't broken, by removing `/-` on line 456 of MathlibTest/polyrith.lean

suggestion:
```suggestion
def sageCreateQuery (Î± : Expr) (atoms : Nat) (hyps : Array (Source Ã— Poly)) (target : Poly) :
```
since I'm not super familiar with sage, could you quickly explain why the syntax of `serialize_polinomials` has changed? (i.e. afaik this is the only change in python query code in this PR)

In the script scripts/polyrith_sage_helper.py, I wanted to make things cleaner by serializing all data using JSON and the `json` Python library. In the previous code the string printed was like `1;[...]` where `[...]` is output from `serialize_polynomials` which serialized things by direct string manipulation (e.g. the previous `arr` function). Now `serialize_polynomials` directly outputs `{"power": 1, "coeffs": [...]}` serialized using `json.dumps`.

suggestion
```suggestion
let data := s!"code={System.Uri.escapeUri query}"
```

```suggestion
      s!"sage_query({sageTypeStr Î±}, {varsStringListPython}, {varsListPython}, {target}, {hypsListPython})"
```
of course @eric-wieser is right. would it be possible to extract this code back into `scripts/polyrith_sage.py` and have here only this kind of call?

This is a little tricky because the hyps list refers to the vars list, but you could do something like
```
sage_query("Q", lambda x, y, z: ([x*2 = 0, x*y = z], x^2*y = 0))` and use `inspect.signature` to discover the argument names
```

Thanks! I did the suggested change. The final function call is more like: `main(QQ, atoms, lambda vars: [vars[0]*2, vars[0]*vars[1] - vars[2]], lambda vars: vars[0]^2*vars[1])`. This avoids using n-ary Python functions where `n` is variable.
Looks great, thanks!
Did you mean to annotate with this?
Oops, nice catch. I wanted to annotate `make_hyps` but I don't know what the return type should be. I removed this import for now

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore(Tactic/Polyrith): remove polyrith dependency on Python
